gen:ReportedAttribute.com:Text: Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3.1 By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality rate to below 70 per 100,000 live births
3.1.1. Maternal mortality ratio
ISTEEBU
NDAYISENGA Modest
Department of Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring, Ponit focal ODD
Head of Service and Focal Point
ndayimode2010@gmail.com

These are the deaths of women recorded during pregnancy, childbirth or after childbirth, whether in health structures or in the community. The denominator is estimated from data from the population projection. The ratio between the number of women who died during pregnancy, childbirth or after childbirth, whether in health facilities or in the community, and the number of births
Number of women per hundred thousand live births
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2021 (Next DHS)
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the demographic and health situation of the population.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which is very resource intensive.

The indicator measures the deaths of women during pregnancy, childbirth or after childbirth, both in health facilities and in the community. The denominator is estimated from data from the population projection.
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the Demographic and Health Survey 2016-2017
Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3.1 By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality rate to below 70 per 100,000 live births
3.1.2. Percentage of births attended by trained health personnel
ISTEEBU
NDAYISENGA Modest
Department of Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring, Ponit focal ODD
Head of Service and Focal Point
ndayimode2010@gmail.com
it is the number of deliveries attended by qualified health personnel (doctor, midwife, nurse) and the total number of pregnancies expected during the last 12 months
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2021 (Next DHS)
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the demographic and health situation of the population.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which is very resource intensive.
Ratio between the number of deliveries conducted by a person with at least the qualification of auxiliary birth attendant and the total number of deliveries multiplied by 100.
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level, province, area of residence (Total; Urban area; Rural area)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the Demographic and Health Survey 2016-2017
Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages

3.2 By 2030, eliminate preventable deaths of infants and children under 5, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to 12 per 1,000 live births or less and child mortality under 5 from 5 years to 25 per 1,000 live births at most
3.2.1. Prevalence of underweight in children under 5 years old
ISTEEBU
NDAYISENGA Modest
Department of Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring, Ponit focal ODD
Head of Service and Focal Point
ndayimode2010@gmail.com
Proportion of children who are underweight for their age.
Nutritional surveys
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2020
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reports on the nutritional situation of children under 5 and the food security of the population.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which requires a lot of resources and most of which is donated by partners
Proportion of children under 5 years of age who are underweight for their age in relation to the total number of children under 5 years old.
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level, province, Place of residence (Total; Girls; Boys; 0-11 months; 12-23 months; 24-59 months)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the Survey on the Nutritional Situation and Food Security in Burundi

Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages

3.2 By 2030, eliminate preventable deaths of infants and children under 5, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to 12 per 1,000 live births or less and child mortality under 5 from 5 years to 25 per 1,000 live births at most
3.2.2. Infant and child mortality rate
ISTEEBU
NDAYISENGA Modest
Department of Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring, Ponit focal ODD
Head of Service and Focal Point
ndayimode2010@gmail.com
This is the number of deaths per 100,000 live births
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2021 (Next DHS)
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the demographic and health situation of the population.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which is very resource intensive.
Ratio of the number of children under 5 who died to the total number of children under 5 per 100,000 live births during a given period
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level, province, Place of residence (Total; Girls; Boys; Urban area; Rural area)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the Demographic and Health Survey 2016-2017

Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3.3 By 2030, end the epidemic of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases
3.3.1. HIV / AIDS prevalence rate (15 - 49 years
MSPLS
NIYUNGEKO Jacqueline
niyungeko.jacqueline@gmail.com
The HIV / AIDS prevalence rate (15-49 years) is the proportion of the population aged 15 to 49 who test positive for HIV / AIDS in relation to the total population aged 15 to 49
Health statistics yearbook
Data is collected from administrative registers of health facilities
Collection is done annually
Every year
MSPLS
MSPLS
The Ministerial departments are the members of the SSN whose mission is to collect, process and disseminate the data of their sector.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the health situation in Burundi.
Updating the indicator requires exhaustive collection in health facilities. For most of the data, data from private health facilities are not taken into account.
Ratio of the population aged 15 to 49 tested positive for HIV / AIDS to the total population aged 15 to 49 multiplied by 100
The results of the data collection are validated at two levels: internal validation and validation at the CTIS level before publication
The indicator is available at national level and by sex. (Total; Women; Men)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Health statistics yearbook
Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3.3 By 2030, end the epidemic of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases
3.3.2. HIV testing rate
MSPLS
NIYUNGEKO Jacqueline
niyungeko.jacqueline@gmail.com
The testing rate is an indicator that shows the percentage of people who have been tested and are aware of their HIV status in the total population
Health statistics yearbook
Data is collected from administrative registers of health facilities
Collection is done annually
Every year
MSPLS
MSPLS
The Ministerial departments are the members of the SSN whose mission is to collect, process and disseminate the data of their sector.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the health situation in Burundi.
Updating the indicator requires exhaustive collection in health facilities. For most of the data, data from private health facilities are not taken into account.
(Total number of people screened divided by Total population) multiplied by 100
The results of the data collection are validated at two levels: internal validation and validation at the CTIS level before publication
The indicator is available by gender. (Total; Women; Men)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Health statistics yearbook
Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3.3 By 2030, end the epidemic of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases
3.3.3. Coverage of PMTCT services (Prevention of Materno-Child transmission of HIV AIDS
MSPLS
NIYUNGEKO Jacqueline
niyungeko.jacqueline@gmail.com
This is the proportion of pregnant women who test positive for HIV / AIDS who are on PMTCT compared to all women who test positive for HIV / AIDS during a given period.
Health statistics yearbook
Data is collected from administrative registers of health facilities
Collection is done annually
Every year
MSPLS
MSPLS
The Ministerial departments are the members of the SSN whose mission is to collect, process and disseminate the data of their sector.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the health situation in Burundi.
Updating the indicator requires exhaustive collection in health facilities. For most of the data, data from private health facilities are not taken into account.

(Number of pregnant women who tested positive for HIV who are on PMTCT during a given period divided by the total number of women who tested positive for HIV during that same period) multiplied by 100.
The results of the data collection are validated at two levels: internal validation and validation at the CTIS level before publication
The indicator is available at national level.
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Health statistics yearbook
Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3.3 By 2030, end the epidemic of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases
3.3.4. Malaria prevalence rate <5 years
MSPLS
NIYUNGEKO Jacqueline
niyungeko.jacqueline@gmail.com
The prevalence of malaria is the number of cases of malaria for children under 5 out of the total number of children under 5.
Health statistics yearbook
Data is collected from administrative registers of health facilities
Collection is done annually
Every year
MSPLS
MSPLS
The Ministerial departments are the members of the SSN whose mission is to collect, process and disseminate the data of their sector.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the health situation in Burundi.
Updating the indicator requires exhaustive collection in health facilities. For most of the data, data from private health facilities are not taken into account.
(Number of malaria cases for children under 5 divided by the total number of children under 5) multiplied by 100.
The results of the data collection are validated at two levels: internal validation and validation at the CTIS level before publication
The indicator is available at national level.
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Health statistics yearbook
Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3.3 By 2030, end the epidemic of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases
3.3.5. Notification rate for all forms of tuberculosis
MSPLS
NIYUNGEKO Jacqueline
niyungeko.jacqueline@gmail.com
It is the ratio of positive tests for all forms of tuberculosis compared to the cases detected
For hundred miles
Health statistics yearbook
Data is collected from administrative registers of health facilities
Collection is done annually
Every year
MSPLS
MSPLS
The Ministerial departments are the members of the SSN whose mission is to collect, process and disseminate the data of their sector.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the health situation in Burundi.
Updating the indicator requires exhaustive collection in health facilities. For most of the data, data from private health facilities are not taken into account.
Ratio of positive tests for all forms of tuberculosis to all cases detected, multiplied by 100,000
The results of the data collection are validated at two levels: internal validation and validation at the CTIS level before publication
The indicator is available at national level.
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Health statistics yearbook
Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages

3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and ensure that the reproductive health in national strategies and programs
3.7.1. Contraceptive prevalence rate for women in unions (in%)
ISTEEBU
NDAYISENGA Modest
Department of Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring, Ponit focal ODD
Head of Service and Focal Point
ndayimode2010@gmail.com
It is the ratio between women aged 15 to 49 in union who use a contraceptive method and all women aged 15 to 49 in union during the year.
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2021 (Next DHS)
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the demographic and health situation of the population.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which is very resource intensive.

(Number of women aged 15 to 49 in union who used a contraceptive method during the year in question divided by the total number of women aged 15 to 49 in union minus the number of pregnancies expected during the year. year) multiplied by 100
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level, province, area of residence (Total; Urban area; Rural area)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the Demographic and Health Survey 2016-2017
Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages

3.8 Ensure that everyone has universal health coverage, including protection against financial risks and providing access to quality essential health services and to safe, effective, quality and cost-effective essential medicines and vaccines. affordable
3.8.1. % of children fully immunized
ISTEEBU
NDAYISENGA Modest
Department of Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring, Ponit focal ODD
Head of Service and Focal Point
ndayimode2010@gmail.com
This is the proportion of children aged 12 to 23 months who received all doses of vaccines
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2021 (Next DHS)
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the demographic and health situation of the population.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which is very resource intensive.
Number of children aged 12 to 23 months who received all doses of vaccine multiplied by 100 and divided by the expected population of 12 to 23 months.
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level, province, area of residence (Total; Urban area; Rural area)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the Demographic and Health Survey 2016-2017
Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages

3.8 Ensure that everyone has universal health coverage, including protection against financial risks and providing access to quality essential health services and to safe, effective, quality and cost-effective essential medicines and vaccines. affordable
3.8.2. Coverage of PMTCT services (Prevention of Materno-Childhood Transmission of HIV)
MSPLS
NIYUNGEKO Jacqueline
niyungeko.jacqueline@gmail.com
This is the proportion of pregnant women who test positive for HIV / AIDS who are on PMTCT compared to all women who test positive for HIV / AIDS during a given period.
Health statistics yearbook
Data is collected from administrative registers of health facilities
Collection is done annually
Every year
MSPLS
MSPLS
The Ministerial departments are the members of the SSN whose mission is to collect, process and disseminate the data of their sector.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the health situation in Burundi.
Updating the indicator requires exhaustive collection in health facilities. For most of the data, data from private health facilities are not taken into account.

(Number of pregnant women who tested positive for HIV who are on PMTCT during a given period divided by the total number of women who tested positive for HIV during that same period) multiplied by 100.
The results of the data collection are validated at two levels: internal validation and validation at the CTIS level before publication
The indicator is available at national level.
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Health statistics yearbook

Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3.a Strengthen in all countries, as appropriate, the implementation of the World Health Organization's Framework Convention on Tobacco Control
3.a.1.Prevalence of current tobacco consumption among those over 15 years of age (comparative rates by age)
ISTEEBU
NDAYISENGA Modest
Department of Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring, Ponit focal ODD
Head of Service and Focal Point
ndayimode2010@gmail.com
It is the proportion of people aged 15 and over who use tobacco compared to the entire population aged 15 and over
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2021 (Next DHS)
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the demographic and health situation of the population.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which is very resource intensive.
Ratio of people aged 15 and over who use tobacco to the population aged 15 and over, multiplied by 100
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Demographic and Health Survey Report
Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages

3.b Support research and development of vaccines and drugs against diseases, communicable or not, which mainly affect the inhabitants of developing countries, provide affordable access to essential drugs and vaccines, in accordance with the Declaration Doha Round of the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) and Public Health, which reaffirms the right of developing countries to take full advantage of the flexibility provisions of this agreement when it comes to protecting public health and, in particular, ensuring universal access to medicines
3.b.2. Total net amount of official development assistance devoted to medical research and basic health care
It is the proportion of public expenditure allocated to health research to total public expenditure on health.
Ratio of public spending on health research to total public spending on health, expressed as a percentage.
Not available
Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages

3.b Support research and development of vaccines and drugs against diseases, communicable or not, which mainly affect the inhabitants of developing countries, provide affordable access to essential drugs and vaccines, in accordance with the Declaration Doha Round of the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) and Public Health, which reaffirms the right of developing countries to take full advantage of the flexibility provisions of this agreement when it comes to protecting public health and, in particular, ensuring universal access to medicines
3.b.2. Total net amount of official development assistance devoted to medical research and basic health care
It is the proportion of public expenditure allocated to health research to total public expenditure on health.
Ratio of public spending on health research to total public spending on health, expressed as a percentage.
Not available
Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages

3.c Substantially increase the health budget and the recruitment, development, training and retention of health personnel in developing countries, especially in least developed countries and small island developing States
3.c.1.Density and distribution of health personnel
MSPLS
NIYUNGEKO Jacqueline
niyungeko.jacqueline@gmail.com
It is the number of the population by health personnel (different categories).
Number of people by category of health personnel
Health statistics yearbook
Data is collected from administrative registers of health facilities
Collection is done annually
Every year
MSPLS
MSPLS
The Ministerial departments are the members of the SSN whose mission is to collect, process and disseminate the data of their sector.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the health situation in Burundi.
Updating the indicator requires exhaustive collection in health facilities. For most of the data, data from private health facilities are not taken into account.
Total population divided by the number of staff per category.
The results of the data collection are validated at two levels: internal validation and validation at the CTIS level before publication
The indicator is available at national level.
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Health statistics yearbook
Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages

Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages

3.b Support research and development of vaccines and drugs against diseases, communicable or not, which mainly affect the inhabitants of developing countries, provide affordable access to essential drugs and vaccines, in accordance with the Declaration Doha Round of the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) and Public Health, which reaffirms the right of developing countries to take full advantage of the flexibility provisions of this agreement when it comes to protecting public health and, in particular, ensuring universal access to medicines
3.b.3.Proportion of health facilities with a constant supply of essential drugs at an affordable cost
This is the percentage of health facilities that have a constant supply of essential drugs at an affordable cost compared to all health facilities
Ratio of health facilities with constant access to an affordable set of essential drugs to all health facilities, multiplied by 100;
Not available
Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages

3.b Support research and development of vaccines and drugs against diseases, communicable or not, which mainly affect the inhabitants of developing countries, provide affordable access to essential drugs and vaccines, in accordance with the Declaration Doha Round of the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) and Public Health, which reaffirms the right of developing countries to take full advantage of the flexibility provisions of this agreement when it comes to protecting public health and, in particular, ensuring universal access to medicines
3.b.1.Proportion of the population able to obtain essential drugs and vaccines at an affordable cost and in a sustainable manner
Not available
Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages

3.b Support research and development of vaccines and drugs against diseases, communicable or not, which mainly affect the inhabitants of developing countries, provide affordable access to essential drugs and vaccines, in accordance with the Declaration Doha Round of the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) and Public Health, which reaffirms the right of developing countries to take full advantage of the flexibility provisions of this agreement when it comes to protecting public health and, in particular, ensuring universal access to medicines
